In announcing the topic of the essay for the Natural Science group,

statement, rather than diffuse and
rambling."
"The vast majority of essays last
Year," Dean Berry stated, "were
inuch too long and too diffuse, and
Were written all around the topic instead of about it."
In the preparation of the essay
this year, he advised students to:
1. Be concise and specific in
statement, rather than diffuse and
rambling.
2. In using any technical terms,
be sure to make clear what you mean
by them.
3. Illustrate ideas by concrete
examples.
4. Draw up a bibliography of
the books actually consulted.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., TUESDAY, DECEMBER 19. 1933

Wm. Follmer Made C.W.A. Expected To Approve
Chairman OfJunior
University Road Paving Plan
Prom Committee
William Follmer has been appointed chairman of the Junior
Prom Commitee, it was announced Friday by Bernard Merson, president of the class.
The other members of the
committee include Harvey Lesselbaum, George Chinsley, John
Mitchell, Rogers Bartlett, S. McKendrick and J. Ryan.
Merson also stated that the
prom will not be held in conjunction with June Week, as was the
case last year, but will be moved
up to an earlier date, probably
during March. Several wellknown orchestras are being contacted for the affair.

Decision Due This Week; Work Begins Immediately On
Campus Improvement Project; Financed
By Federal Bureau
Confidence that government financing for paved roads and other
campus improvement would be approved by Federal authorities was
expressed yesterday by Maxwell
Sauerwein, assistant treasurer of
the University. Final decision is
expected before the end of this
week.
Appropriation of funds for work
on the University grounds will be
made by the Civil Works Administration. A list of needed repairs was
submitted to that bureau by Pres.
Joseph S. Ames, subsequent to investigations and plans made by Dr.
J. T. Thompson, professor of civil
engineering, and his associates.

A milestone in undergraduate activity history will be marked tonight
when the Musical Club, oldest and
largest of campus activities, opens
its fiftieth season at Trinity Church,
Liberty Heights and Wabash Avenues. About seventy members will
participate in the program.
Founded in October, 1883, by a
group of men who later became
conspicuous in public life, the club
has held a place of high regard
among musically-inclined students.
Officers of the organization are preparing plans for a fiftieth anniversary celebration, to be held at the
annual Home Concert and Dance at
the Maryland Casualty Clubhouse
next February 23rd. Arrangements
for a graduate reunion in honor of
the occasion are being made, and it
is expected that a large representation of early memberships of the
group will attend the Home Concert.
Famous Men Have Participated

Participants in the founding of
the Musical Club, which was originally only a glee club but now has
added three instrumental groups,
included the late President Woodrow Wilson, Arthur Yeager, exGovernor of Porto Rico, Albert
Shaw, editor of the Review of Reviews; Charles Levermore, winner
of the Bok Peace Award; and Walter Hines Page, founder of the
Page School of International Relations at the Hopkins. Newton D.
Baker and Dr. Alan M. Chesney;
dean of the Hopkins Medical Faculty, together with other prominent
figures of political and academic
life, have appeared on the roster of
the Club.

THE NEWS-LETTER last week has
been added a trip to the Hotel Chalfonte-Haddon Hall, Atlantic City,
next March 10th. Notice of accepted members in the Club was
posted yesterday at the post office.

Ex-Goettigen Professor Emigrated From Germany,
Protesting Nazism
Dr. James Franck, who was
awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1926, will be the James
Speyer Visiting Professor during the spring semester.
Until recently, Dr. Franck was
professor of physics at the University of Goettingen but has
voluntarily emigrated from Germany as a protest against the
Nazi anti-Semetic campaign.
Discoverer of the basic foundation of the quantum theory,
Dr. Franck is regarded as an authority on photochemistry and
the general property of atoms
and molecules.

Discusses Hullabaloo

Ted Stern, editor of the Hullabaloo, discussed plans for the issue
of the yearbook and urged the support of the entire class. With medicine as its theme, the yearbook will
feature thirty etchings and four
four-colored plates. It is planned
to enter the Hullabaloo in the annual yearbook contest.
Bob Powell, chairman of the June
Week committee, proposed a shorter
and less expensive June Week. He
explained that the deficit from last
year's affair was $800. As a result,
small and expensive affairs will be
dropped from this year's program.
Although final plans have not been
made, Powell urged the support of
the entire class in this affair. The
deadline for the payments have
been set for March 1.
Prompt Payment Urged

Myron Halsbond, treasurer of the
class, has been authorized to appoint
two assistant treasurers, who will
assist him. Senior dues may be paid
at the Hullabaloo office or at the
postoffice.
"We urge all seniors to make
prompt payment of dues so that defnite plans may be completed for the
next year, declared John G. Weeks,
president of the class. He added,
"I think that we have arranged
one of the finest list of activities
that any senior class at the Hopkins has ever attempted."

Commission To Hear
Dai On China Tonight
P. L. Dai, graduate student in
Political Science at the 'Hopkins,
a native of Canton, China, will
be the guest speaker of the
Freshman Commission at their
meeting this evening in Levering Hall. He will discuss "The
Political Situation in China Today."
Besides being a student at the
Hopkins, Dai is an instructor in
Chinese at the University. He
graduated from Shanghai College, China, before coming to the
United States to continue his
studies, and at present spends
most of his time in Washington,
D. C.

12:30 today, it was announced by
Dr. William S. Holt. Important
matters relating to the group will
be discussed at the meeting.

Tuesday, December 19, 1933

Jack-in-the-Box
The race question is always with us. After having
hovered around the outskirts of our cloistered campus life it is being more and more forced upon our
attention by the activity of interested students and
the local colored press.
At present the concern is about the recent barring
of a colored New York high school student from
the cross-country meet sponsored by the Spiked Shoe
at the Hopkins. The Liberal Club attempted to investigate the conditions of the barring but could get
no further than the knowledge that Coach Hambleton, for reasons unannounced, had made the ruling.
In the meantime, the Afro-American headlined the
affair.
As to what method a conscientious seeker after
interracial amity should pursue in protesting a development of this sort we are at a loss to suggest. Intellectual honesty practically forces a reaction of some
sort. But there is the constant problem of how to
go about achieving any readjustment of relations
between white and colored people.
Frankly and clearly, the whole affair is based on
prejudice. Any further elaboration is bound to be
artificial because the whole idea of Negro inferiority
has grown from a conceited realization on the part of
white men that their own advantages are more numerous than are those of the Negroes. Some men
are more lenient than others in their opposition and
would sanction intermingling of races to some extent,
but still drawing the line on social and personal association.
In the face of conditions as they are, however, it
seems at first blush to be poor technique to continually
force the prejudiced to explain themselves. Every
attack upon them only causes them to recede farther
into their social shells and to build up more and more
rationalization for their mental bias. Reason invoked in such circumstances is vicious and is the
cloak for a passion, to borrow the idea advanced by
Prof. Reinhold Niebuhr at Supper Club last week.
Nothing but trial and error will ever show what's
the right method of achieving reform. But the objection to forcing prejudiced persons into rationalizing their actions is obvious.

About Two Attitudes
Commendation unreserved is due the Barnstormers for a creditable showing of "Front Page" last
Saturday. The cast caught the spirit of the piece in
fine fashion and gave good account of itself.
Worthy of equal note, however, is the fact that
performance was given on less than half of the normal budgetary appropriation for Barnstormer seasons.
Finding themselves under the necessity of cutting
down on every expenditure the first economy was to
shift to a less expensive hall for the grand occasion
and with scarcely any loss in patronage, because the
Maryland Casualty affords as pleasant facilities as
the Lyric. Second, they cut the show to one night
rather than the usual two, making it possible to sell
out the house once and not having to give out free
tickets in order to fill it twice.
It is a characteristic of most of us that when we
are in a tight place we'll work our way out some way
or another. The activities are showing an
admirable spirit this year in recognizing the impossbility of getting financial support from the University. If there was ever cause to complain about the
University's taking $1000 from the S. A. C. fund
there is this year, when the funds are missed more
than ever before. But through some sort of a spirit
of loyalty to the institution which has not made itself
evident hertofore the leaders are undertaking their
work with a minimum of grumbling.
It's an attitude which would be well rewarded by
the administration in taking the activities heads into
its confidence. The method of dealing so far has
been very peremptory and impersonal when the times
have indicated a particular need for teamwork. It is
rather a shame that the authorities have not been able
to separate themselves from the notion that dictating
is the means of securing the best out of students in
extra-curricular work. A lesson in psychology might
help the official technique a little.

Nobody's Business
THINKING THAT it was about time to descend
upon the History Department, I wandered along the
third floor of Gilman until I came to the offices of
those purveyors of history, who inhabit that part of
the building. Without any malice aforethought, I
knocked on Dr. Painter's door, and hearing "Come",
I straightway came. Dr. Painter was ensconced, and
from all 'appearances, comfortably, in an antique
Morris chair. After stating my business, he said he
was willing to be interviewed, "if it'll do you any
good," he added. He settled back in his chair, lighted his pipe, and tossed the match towards the wastebasket which, unfortunately, he missed.
DR. PAINTER got both his A.B. and Ph.D. at
Yale, where, afterwards, he taught history for a
while. He came to the Hopkins year before last. He
spent the summer holiday tramping around England
looking up Old castles, which is one of his favorite
subjects. He also likes to fish, but he said, "I rarely
have the time to pursue that worthy pastime."

"The Front Page"
ductions of this nature. The
characters all looked one age,
despite the fact that the play
called for wide differences. On
one occasion, a young girl entered through a door, that had
been carefully locked; in another
instance the temptation was too
great to make a not-at-all effective allusion to the current negro
troubles in Maryland. The reporters always talked several feet
above the telephones and were
at time more attentive to the effect of their lines on the audience than to the actual business
at hand. The production manager (and this always happens!)
had to peep from the wings from
time to time to the distraction of
many spectators.
BUT THESE are rather uninteresting observations that would
appeal only to those more technically experienced in the actual
presentation of a play. The audience, in general, was not disturbed; the lines were sufficiently humorous to carry the play
through any faults of production.
THE REPORTERS acted
well, especially Bert I. Gordon.
Miss Jeanette Sauters gave an
excellent characterization of a
woman of the streets turned romantic. Miss Kathryn W. Forsythe had one or two effective
scenes, especially in the second
act when she was called upon to
emit a magnificently blood-curdling scream. Charles Squire
brought into the leading part all
the vivacity that it demanded.
ROBERT
WATKINS, a
freshman, in the role of Sheriff
Hartman, showed that he has the
makings of a really effective actor. Miss Elizabeth S. Ullman
and Louis Hartman handled
their difficult roles well. But the
best acting was exhibited by
Philip S. Criblet, playing the
part of Walter Burns, who had
the situation always under command in anger, excitement, despair, or the final flush of victory.

Swimmers Impress
By Speedy Trials

PERHAPS no more striking proof of the impotence of designating
any eleven football players as the All-American team is furnished by
the recent most valuable player elections held by the various squads.
THE RESULTS of the first three of these elections to be made
public bear out our viewpoint. They follow:
1.—Michigan, generally considered the strongest team in the country, has seen Fred Petoskey, Chuck Bernard, and Francis Wistert honored by being placed on most All-American elevens. Yet the Wolverines at their annual banquet named Herman Everhardus, hard-hitting
halfback, as their most valuable player.
2.—Purdue, second only to Michigan in the Big Ten. Experts have
singled out Duane Purvis, Paul Pardonner, Dutch Fehring and Fritz
Febel as the most deserving Boilermaker gridders. Yet the team accorded most valuable player honors to Fred Hecker, fullback.
3.—Notre Dame, with Ed Krause and Nick Lukats seemingly its
outstanding representatives, chose Ray Brancheau as most valuable to
the team.
BUT WHEN the experts try to be dogmatic to the point of limiting
their preference to a single team, the value of such players as Everhardus, Hecker, and Brancheau is likely to be forgotten by the credulous sporting populace. That is our chief objection to an All-American,
and that is why we suggest in its stead an honor roll, which need not be
hampered by the spectre of eleven and only eleven names as its capacity,
but which will be as all inclusive as merit demands.

Maryland-Indiana Game
Aids State Football
CONGRATULATIONS to the athletic officials of the University
of Maryland for their evident desire to put the State on the football
map once again. With the announcement of their scheduling a home-andhome series with Indiana, the local game to be played at the Stadium
in 1935, the Old Liners have certainly come to the aid of Navy in attempting to revive the waning of football interest in Baltimore.
THIS LEAVES but one open date on the Terrapins' schedule, which
calls for games with Navy, Florida (at the Stadium), Indiana, and
Hopkins, in addition to five other settos. Anent the Hopkins game, a
local sports writer had this to say last Saturday:
"The Hopkins game is fading into insignificance. Maryland continues to meet Hopkins on the gridiron simply because
it is a old rivalry and some of the alumni would feel badly if
the game were dropped."
IF WE were desirous of finding vindication for our recent argument
subject, our quest might easily end here. But it seems the conthe

Freshmen Prove Especially Promising As Time Tests Produce
Excellent Performances
Final tryouts for the members of
the swimming team were held last
Friday at the Knights of Columbus
pool. Every swimmer was clocked
in his specialty, and the candidates
with the best time in each event
were selected to remain on the
squad.
The outstanding performances in
the sprint events were made by
Frank Levi and Charles Bahlke, veterans from last year, who gave evidence that they will be in even better form for this season.
Adler Impresses

Louis Adler, a distance swimmer
from the 1932 freshman aggregation, proved by his time Friday that
he will be a valuable addition to the
team. Bill Hazlett, another sophomore, turned in greatly improved
time for the 100-yard breaststroke,
and is rivaling Eddie Sadtler for
top honors in this event.
The freshmen were also given a
hard workout in preparation for a
practice meet with Poly today at the
City College natatorium. Among
the outstanding first year men who
will swim against the Engineers are
Eddie Scheer, in the sprint events;
Dan Weiner, in the backstroke;
Buddy Adler in the 220, and Bill
Koenig in the dive.

University Of Baltimore
Has The Right Idea
COLLEGIATE basketball in Maryland is also in the process of
taking on an intersectional aspect, and that is significant. However,
what to us is far more significant is the fact that the University of Baltimore happens to be one of the schools actively engaged in the movement.
IT IS well known that the U. of B. is not the wealthiest of universities, and yet we observe that it brought Duke University to Carlin's
Park last Friday and has scheduled Georgie Tech for the same location
on Dceember 28. This would seem to indicate that perhaps an effervescence of funds is not needed to play host to big-time teams.
WE DON'T know whether the Maroons profited or lost by the
affair. Regardless of the financial aspect, they have gained immeasurably in the eyes of Baltimore's sporting populace for having had the
courage of their convictions during these times.
PERHAPS Hopkins can profit by this example. We get so tired
of reading that they're going to play Army, Temple, and N. Y. U., at
Army, Temple, and N. Y. U.

Grapplers Succumb
To F. &M. Rivals
By 36-0 Decision
Lancaster, Pa., Dec. 16.—The
Johns Hopkins wrestling team lost
its second meet of the season to
Franklin and Marshall College, by
a score of 36-0. The match was
extremely one-sided from the start,
the Pennsylvanians showing themselves far superior to the Jays
throughout the entire match.
Only two Hopkins grapplers—
Mitchell, 165 pounds, and Connor.
175 lbs., were able to hold out long
enough to be defeated by time advantages. The rest of the Black and
Blue matmen were thrown before
the regular time for the bout.
The Blue Jays will take a rest
during the holidays but have several
important matches scheduled during
the month of January.

Makeshift Line-Up Holds
Strong Rival To 4-0
Margin
JAY DEFENSE
PROVES FIRM
Lack Of Replacements For
Forwards Prevents Scoring Threats
Playing its first practice game
of the season, the Johns Hopkins
hockey club took a 4-0 defeat at
the hands of the Baltimore Athletic Club. The contest took
place Sunday morning at the
Sports Centre Rink.
However, the 4-0 loss is not as
discomfiting as it seems, for the
Jays, playing under the handicap
of insufficient substitutes, exhibited a better brand of defensive hockey than they have displayed in the past two seasons.
Arthur Phillips, Henry Beeler,
and Ed Schmeisser showed remarkable ability in keeping the
Red and White skaters away
from shooting distance to the
goal, while Ross Jones, Hopkins
goalie, was in tip-top form.
Many Veterans Absent

The point of weakness was the
forward line, for the trio of
Dukehart, Houck and Pons hardly had three capable substitutes
who could relieve them for a few
minute's rest. Consequently the
above mentioned were forced to
play most of the second and third
periods when they were exhausted.
Bill Nickel, Bob McCurdy,
George Packard, Guerny Dayette
and Happy Day were unable to
get to practice Sunday morning,
causing the lack of proper reserves. However, Hopkins shows
signs of having a team that will
be stronger than last season, and
certainly capable of playing the
game on a par with the other
members of the league during the
second half of the campaign
which begins in January.

LIBERAL CLUB
PICKS DELEGATE
FOR CONVENTION
Neal Potter To Represent
Homewood Group At
Political Conclave
THOMAS, FISH,
ROPER TO SPEAK
Dr. Broadus Mitchell To
Lead Round-Table
Discussion
Plans were made by the Liberal Club at its meeting last Friday for sending delegates to the
coming National Conference on
Students in Politics, in Wash)ington, D. C., December 29-30.
One member, Neal Potter, was
definitely designated to attend,
while others were not sure that they
would be able to get to Washington.
In the absence of Richard
Feise, the president, W. R.
Kanne presided, and plans were
formed for the next meeting of
the club, to be held on Friday,
January 5, for which a discussion
of books on war was tentatively
set. Discussion also centered on
the question of holding a student
conference on some important
question of the day, such as convened last year.
Leaders To Speak

The Washington conference
will be addressed by many of the
leading men in political thought
today, such as Norman Thomas,
Hamilton Fish, and Daniel C.
Roper (tentative). Dr. Broadus
Mitchell, of the Hopkins, is also
expected to attend, leading a
round-table conference on the
question, "How can we settle
our minority problem?"
The conference will take in
colleges from all over the country, and will attempt to answer
in some degree the questions:
Does the N. R. A. mean recovery
—retrogression—revolution? Is
another World War imminent?
Have students a responsibility in
these matters?

Railway Express, Inc.
Offers Suggestions
To Homebound Men
Railway Express Agency, Inc.,
advances the following pertinent
suggestions to Hopkins students
who are returning home with luggage for the Christmas vacation:
1. Remove all "old addresses".
2. Give full name and address of
both shipper and consignee.
3. Mark valuation.
4. Use sturdy shipping tags.
5. Place your name and address
inside each piece (for emergency
identification in event of loss of
outer labels).
6. Avoid shipping of fragile or
liquid articles if possible. Otherwise pack and cushion well and
mark "Fragile".

“News-Letter" Hound Discovers
Spectator of Past At Hopkins

SCIENCE
Last week Time celebrated its
anniversary! All over the country 50 years ago clocks were readjusted to standard time, based
on the seventy-fifth meridian of
longitude.
Professor Charles Ferdinand
Dowd laid out four time zones,
which he caled Eastern, Central,
Mountain and Pacific.
Prior to this idea; a confusion
existed which is hard to realize.
There were 75 different kinds of
railroad time. Each community
had its own peculiar variety of
time.
Now Time is based on the
movement of the sun. The sun
moves across fifteen degrees of
longitude every hour. It was this
constant that Dr. Dowd took as
the basis for his standard time
system.

surrounds the spectators of the
past, whether they be writings,

one every afternoon a gentleman,

and thought.

since its inception. Thus there
has existed no time in the history
of the University when Mr.

not maintained a quiet, but useful, part of its organization. His

that Golden Age when years ago

Mr. Stuart believes a great deal
more is the reality of those days
than in the consciousness of the
present. So there is in our midst
a very vivid link to enliven the
hazy chain of college traditions.

In announcing the topic of the essay for the Natural Science group,
bean E. W. Berry advised that all

statement, rather than diffuse and
rambling."
"The vast majority of essays last
Year," Dean Berry stated, "were
inuch too long and too diffuse, and
Were written all around the topic instead of about it."
In the preparation of the essay
this year, he advised students to:
1. Be concise and specific in
statement, rather than diffuse and
rambling.
2. In using any technical terms,
be sure to make clear what you mean
by them.
3. Illustrate ideas by concrete
examples.
4. Draw up a bibliography of
the books actually consulted.

A milestone in undergraduate activity history will be marked tonight
when the Musical Club, oldest and
largest of campus activities, opens
its fiftieth season at Trinity Church,
Liberty Heights and Wabash Avenues. About seventy members will
participate in the program.
Founded in October, 1883, by a
group of men who later became
conspicuous in public life, the club
has held a place of high regard
among musically-inclined students.
Officers of the organization are preparing plans for a fiftieth anniversary celebration, to be held at the
annual Home Concert and Dance at
the Maryland Casualty Clubhouse
next February 23rd. Arrangements
for a graduate reunion in honor of
the occasion are being made, and it
is expected that a large representation of early memberships of the
group will attend the Home Concert.
Famous Men Have Participated

Participants in the founding of
the Musical Club, which was originally only a glee club but now has
added three instrumental groups,
included the late President Woodrow Wilson, Arthur Yeager, exGovernor of Porto Rico, Albert
Shaw, editor of the Review of Reviews; Charles Levermore, winner
of the Bok Peace Award; and Walter Hines Page, founder of the
Page School of International Relations at the Hopkins. Newton D.
Baker and Dr. Alan M. Chesney;
dean of the Hopkins Medical Faculty, together with other prominent
figures of political and academic
life, have appeared on the roster of
the Club.

awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1926, will be the James

Until recently, Dr. Franck was
professor of physics at the University of Goettingen but has
voluntarily emigrated from Germany as a protest against the
Nazi anti-Semetic campaign.
Discoverer of the basic foundation of the quantum theory,
Dr. Franck is regarded as an authority on photochemistry and
the general property of atoms
and molecules.

Discusses Hullabaloo

Ted Stern, editor of the Hullabaloo, discussed plans for the issue
of the yearbook and urged the support of the entire class. With medicine as its theme, the yearbook will
feature thirty etchings and four
four-colored plates. It is planned
to enter the Hullabaloo in the annual yearbook contest.
Bob Powell, chairman of the June
Week committee, proposed a shorter
and less expensive June Week. He
explained that the deficit from last
year's affair was $800. As a result,
small and expensive affairs will be
dropped from this year's program.
Although final plans have not been
made, Powell urged the support of
the entire class in this affair. The
deadline for the payments have
been set for March 1.
Prompt Payment Urged

Myron Halsbond, treasurer of the
class, has been authorized to appoint
two assistant treasurers, who will
assist him. Senior dues may be paid
at the Hullabaloo office or at the
postoffice.
"We urge all seniors to make
prompt payment of dues so that defnite plans may be completed for the
next year, declared John G. Weeks,
president of the class. He added,
"I think that we have arranged
one of the finest list of activities
that any senior class at the Hopkins has ever attempted."

Commission To Hear
Dai On China Tonight
P. L. Dai, graduate student in
Political Science at the 'Hopkins,
a native of Canton, China, will
be the guest speaker of the
Freshman Commission at their
meeting this evening in Levering Hall. He will discuss "The
Political Situation in China Today."
Besides being a student at the
Hopkins, Dai is an instructor in
Chinese at the University. He
graduated from Shanghai College, China, before coming to the
United States to continue his
studies, and at present spends
most of his time in Washington,
D. C.

Jack-in-the-Box
The race question is always with us. After having
hovered around the outskirts of our cloistered campus life it is being more and more forced upon our
attention by the activity of interested students and
the local colored press.
At present the concern is about the recent barring
of a colored New York high school student from
the cross-country meet sponsored by the Spiked Shoe
at the Hopkins. The Liberal Club attempted to investigate the conditions of the barring but could get
no further than the knowledge that Coach Hambleton, for reasons unannounced, had made the ruling.
In the meantime, the Afro-American headlined the
affair.
As to what method a conscientious seeker after
interracial amity should pursue in protesting a development of this sort we are at a loss to suggest. Intellectual honesty practically forces a reaction of some
sort. But there is the constant problem of how to
go about achieving any readjustment of relations
between white and colored people.
Frankly and clearly, the whole affair is based on
prejudice. Any further elaboration is bound to be
artificial because the whole idea of Negro inferiority
has grown from a conceited realization on the part of
white men that their own advantages are more numerous than are those of the Negroes. Some men
are more lenient than others in their opposition and
would sanction intermingling of races to some extent,
but still drawing the line on social and personal association.
In the face of conditions as they are, however, it
seems at first blush to be poor technique to continually
force the prejudiced to explain themselves. Every
attack upon them only causes them to recede farther
into their social shells and to build up more and more
rationalization for their mental bias. Reason invoked in such circumstances is vicious and is the
cloak for a passion, to borrow the idea advanced by
Prof. Reinhold Niebuhr at Supper Club last week.
Nothing but trial and error will ever show what's
the right method of achieving reform. But the objection to forcing prejudiced persons into rationalizing their actions is obvious.

About Two Attitudes
Commendation unreserved is due the Barnstormers for a creditable showing of "Front Page" last
Saturday. The cast caught the spirit of the piece in
fine fashion and gave good account of itself.
Worthy of equal note, however, is the fact that
performance was given on less than half of the normal budgetary appropriation for Barnstormer seasons.
Finding themselves under the necessity of cutting
down on every expenditure the first economy was to
shift to a less expensive hall for the grand occasion
and with scarcely any loss in patronage, because the
Maryland Casualty affords as pleasant facilities as
the Lyric. Second, they cut the show to one night
rather than the usual two, making it possible to sell
out the house once and not having to give out free
tickets in order to fill it twice.
It is a characteristic of most of us that when we
are in a tight place we'll work our way out some way
or another. The activities are showing an
admirable spirit this year in recognizing the impossbility of getting financial support from the University. If there was ever cause to complain about the
University's taking $1000 from the S. A. C. fund
there is this year, when the funds are missed more
than ever before. But through some sort of a spirit
of loyalty to the institution which has not made itself
evident hertofore the leaders are undertaking their
work with a minimum of grumbling.
It's an attitude which would be well rewarded by
the administration in taking the activities heads into
its confidence. The method of dealing so far has
been very peremptory and impersonal when the times
have indicated a particular need for teamwork. It is
rather a shame that the authorities have not been able
to separate themselves from the notion that dictating
is the means of securing the best out of students in
extra-curricular work. A lesson in psychology might
help the official technique a little.

ducking, on peaches and green beer. The scheme of
finding John's supposed treasure, which has recently
been talked about in the papers, Dr. Painter thinks

Nobody's Business
THINKING THAT it was about time to descend
upon the History Department, I wandered along the
third floor of Gilman until I came to the offices of
those purveyors of history, who inhabit that part of
the building. Without any malice aforethought, I
knocked on Dr. Painter's door, and hearing "Come",
I straightway came. Dr. Painter was ensconced, and
from all 'appearances, comfortably, in an antique
Morris chair. After stating my business, he said he
was willing to be interviewed, "if it'll do you any
good," he added. He settled back in his chair, lighted his pipe, and tossed the match towards the wastebasket which, unfortunately, he missed.
DR. PAINTER got both his A.B. and Ph.D. at
Yale, where, afterwards, he taught history for a
while. He came to the Hopkins year before last. He
spent the summer holiday tramping around England
looking up Old castles, which is one of his favorite
subjects. He also likes to fish, but he said, "I rarely
have the time to pursue that worthy pastime."

"The Front Page"
ductions of this nature. The
characters all looked one age,
despite the fact that the play
called for wide differences. On
one occasion, a young girl entered through a door, that had

instance the temptation was too
great to make a not-at-all effective allusion to the current negro
troubles in Maryland. The reporters always talked several feet
above the telephones and were
at time more attentive to the effect of their lines on the audience than to the actual business
at hand. The production manager (and this always happens!)
had to peep from the wings from
time to time to the distraction of
many spectators.
BUT THESE are rather uninteresting observations that would
appeal only to those more technically experienced in the actual
presentation of a play. The audience, in general, was not disturbed; the lines were sufficiently humorous to carry the play
through any faults of production.
THE REPORTERS acted
well, especially Bert I. Gordon.
Miss Jeanette Sauters gave an
excellent characterization of a
woman of the streets turned romantic. Miss Kathryn W. Forsythe had one or two effective
scenes, especially in the second
act when she was called upon to
emit a magnificently blood-curdling scream. Charles Squire
brought into the leading part all
the vivacity that it demanded.
ROBERT
WATKINS, a
freshman, in the role of Sheriff
Hartman, showed that he has the

and Louis Hartman handled
their difficult roles well. But the
best acting was exhibited by
Philip S. Criblet, playing the
part of Walter Burns, who had
the situation always under command in anger, excitement, despair, or the final flush of victory.

Swimmers Impress
By Speedy Trials

PERHAPS no more striking proof of the impotence of designating
any eleven football players as the All-American team is furnished by
the recent most valuable player elections held by the various squads.
THE RESULTS of the first three of these elections to be made
public bear out our viewpoint. They follow:
1.—Michigan, generally considered the strongest team in the country, has seen Fred Petoskey, Chuck Bernard, and Francis Wistert honored by being placed on most All-American elevens. Yet the Wolverines at their annual banquet named Herman Everhardus, hard-hitting
halfback, as their most valuable player.
2.—Purdue, second only to Michigan in the Big Ten. Experts have
singled out Duane Purvis, Paul Pardonner, Dutch Fehring and Fritz
Febel as the most deserving Boilermaker gridders. Yet the team accorded most valuable player honors to Fred Hecker, fullback.
3.—Notre Dame, with Ed Krause and Nick Lukats seemingly its
outstanding representatives, chose Ray Brancheau as most valuable to
the team.
BUT WHEN the experts try to be dogmatic to the point of limiting
their preference to a single team, the value of such players as Everhardus, Hecker, and Brancheau is likely to be forgotten by the credulous sporting populace. That is our chief objection to an All-American,
and that is why we suggest in its stead an honor roll, which need not be
hampered by the spectre of eleven and only eleven names as its capacity,
but which will be as all inclusive as merit demands.

CONGRATULATIONS to the athletic officials of the University

map once again. With the announcement of their scheduling a home-andhome series with Indiana, the local game to be played at the Stadium

local sports writer had this to say last Saturday:
"The Hopkins game is fading into insignificance. Maryland continues to meet Hopkins on the gridiron simply because
it is a old rivalry and some of the alumni would feel badly if
the game were dropped."

subject, our quest might easily end here. But it seems the conthe

Park last Friday and has scheduled Georgie Tech for the same location

affair. Regardless of the financial aspect, they have gained immeasurably in the eyes of Baltimore's sporting populace for having had the

THE RAMBLERS

11.

Grapplers Succumb
To F. &M. Rivals
By 36-0 Decision
Lancaster, Pa., Dec. 16.—The
Johns Hopkins wrestling team lost
its second meet of the season to
Franklin and Marshall College, by
a score of 36-0. The match was
extremely one-sided from the start,
the Pennsylvanians showing themselves far superior to the Jays
throughout the entire match.
Only two Hopkins grapplers—
Mitchell, 165 pounds, and Connor.
175 lbs., were able to hold out long
enough to be defeated by time advantages. The rest of the Black and
Blue matmen were thrown before
the regular time for the bout.
The Blue Jays will take a rest
during the holidays but have several
important matches scheduled during
the month of January.

•

Makeshift Line-Up Holds
Strong Rival To 4-0
Margin
JAY DEFENSE
PROVES FIRM
Lack Of Replacements For
Forwards Prevents Scoring Threats
Playing its first practice game
of the season, the Johns Hopkins
hockey club took a 4-0 defeat at
the hands of the Baltimore Athletic Club. The contest took
place Sunday morning at the
Sports Centre Rink.
However, the 4-0 loss is not as
discomfiting as it seems, for the
Jays, playing under the handicap
of insufficient substitutes, exhibited a better brand of defensive hockey than they have displayed in the past two seasons.
Arthur Phillips, Henry Beeler,
and Ed Schmeisser showed remarkable ability in keeping the
Red and White skaters away
from shooting distance to the
goal, while Ross Jones, Hopkins
goalie, was in tip-top form.
Many Veterans Absent

The point of weakness was the
forward line, for the trio of
Dukehart, Houck and Pons hardly had three capable substitutes
who could relieve them for a few
minute's rest. Consequently the
above mentioned were forced to
play most of the second and third
periods when they were exhausted.
Bill Nickel, Bob McCurdy,
George Packard, Guerny Dayette
and Happy Day were unable to
get to practice Sunday morning,
causing the lack of proper reserves. However, Hopkins shows
signs of having a team that will
be stronger than last season, and
certainly capable of playing the
game on a par with the other
members of the league during the
second half of the campaign
which begins in January.

LIBERAL CLUB
PICKS DELEGATE
FOR CONVENTION
Neal Potter To Represent
Homewood Group At
Political Conclave
THOMAS, FISH,
ROPER TO SPEAK
Dr. Broadus Mitchell To
Lead Round-Table
Discussion
Plans were made by the Liberal Club at its meeting last Friday for sending delegates to the
coming National Conference on
Students in Politics, in Wash)ington, D. C., December 29-30.
One member, Neal Potter, was
definitely designated to attend,
while others were not sure that they
would be able to get to Washington.
In the absence of Richard
Feise, the president, W. R.
Kanne presided, and plans were
formed for the next meeting of
the club, to be held on Friday,
January 5, for which a discussion
of books on war was tentatively
set. Discussion also centered on
the question of holding a student
conference on some important
question of the day, such as convened last year.
Leaders To Speak

The Washington conference
will be addressed by many of the
leading men in political thought
today, such as Norman Thomas,
Hamilton Fish, and Daniel C.
Roper (tentative). Dr. Broadus
Mitchell, of the Hopkins, is also
expected to attend, leading a
round-table conference on the
question, "How can we settle
our minority problem?"
The conference will take in
colleges from all over the country, and will attempt to answer
in some degree the questions:
Does the N. R. A. mean recovery
—retrogression—revolution? Is
another World War imminent?
Have students a responsibility in
these matters?

Railway Express, Inc.
Offers Suggestions
To Homebound Men
Railway Express Agency, Inc.,
advances the following pertinent
suggestions to Hopkins students
who are returning home with luggage for the Christmas vacation:
1. Remove all "old addresses".
2. Give full name and address of
both shipper and consignee.
3. Mark valuation.
4. Use sturdy shipping tags.
5. Place your name and address
inside each piece (for emergency
identification in event of loss of
outer labels).
6. Avoid shipping of fragile or
liquid articles if possible. Otherwise pack and cushion well and
mark "Fragile".

“News-Letter" Hound Discovers
Spectator of Past At Hopkins

SCIENCE
Last week Time celebrated its
anniversary! All over the country 50 years ago clocks were readjusted to standard time, based
on the seventy-fifth meridian of
longitude.
Professor Charles Ferdinand
Dowd laid out four time zones,
which he caled Eastern, Central,
Mountain and Pacific.
Prior to this idea; a confusion
existed which is hard to realize.
There were 75 different kinds of
railroad time. Each community
had its own peculiar variety of
time.
Now Time is based on the
movement of the sun. The sun
moves across fifteen degrees of
longitude every hour. It was this
constant that Dr. Dowd took as
the basis for his standard time
system.

surrounds the spectators of the
past, whether they be writings,
objects or persons. Within the
post office barriers, unbeknown
to most Hopkins undergraduates, there sits from twelve to
one every afternoon a gentleman,
wrapped in the smoke of his pipe
and thought.
He is seventy-nine years old
and has been at the Hopkins
since its inception. Thus there
has existed no time in the history
of the University when Mr.
Stuart (for that's his name) has
not maintained a quiet, but useful, part of its organization. His
memories easily wander back to
that Golden Age when years ago
Professor Rowlands firmly admitted that he was the greatest
physicist of the country. In fact,
Mr. Stuart believes a great deal
more is the reality of those days
than in the consciousness of the
present. So there is in our midst
a very vivid link to enliven the
hazy chain of college traditions.
